title: Development and Validation of a Questionnaire Measuring Treatment Burden in Pediatric Asthma.
abstract: While treatment burden significantly impacts the management of pediatric asthma, no specific instrument exists to measure it in this population. To develop and validate a questionnaire measuring treatment burden in pediatric asthma from both children's and parents' perspectives. We conducted semi-structured interviews with 20 children (aged 8-12 years) with asthma and their parents to identify relevant components of treatment burden. Items were refined through a Delphi process with pediatric pulmonologists. The questionnaire was then validated in 202 parent-child dyads across eight teaching hospitals. Psychometric properties, including factorial validity, internal consistency, construct validity, and test-retest reliability, were assessed. The final questionnaire comprised 7 items for children (Cronbach's α=0.78) and 13 items for parents (Cronbach's α=0.86). Both versions demonstrated strong construct validity, with significant correlations with quality of life measures (rs=-0.52 for children, rs=-0.53 for parents) and global impression of treatment burden (r=+0.66 for children, r=+0.77 for parents). Test-retest reliability was acceptable for both children (ICC=0.72) and parents (ICC=0.80). Higher treatment burden scores were associated with being female (both for children and caregivers), having multiple scheduled visits, and poor asthma control. Parent and child scores showed moderate correlation (rs=0.33, P<.01), highlighting the importance of capturing both perspectives. This validated questionnaire provides a reliable tool for measuring treatment burden in pediatric asthma, enabling clinicians to better understand and address the impact of asthma management on children and their families.
